ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about science fiction in Latin American countries, and it really helped improve my comprehension.
I learned how to analytically read creative writing and Spanish texts in general.
I developed a theoretical framework to identify, analyze and critique Latin American science fiction.

I learned about various Hispanic-American authors, theories about science fiction literature, and some history. We got to read some really cool science fiction stories and discuss the potential meanings of the works by considering the effects of various literary elements, theories of science fiction, and the historical/geographical context in which they were written.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the class was really strong, the professor was super engaging and really adorable. There's no participation credit, so a lot of students didn't speak during the whole semester. There's definitely room to participate, though, if you want to.
To help with the readings, guiding questions or little notes about the passage before we read them would be helpful to understand what to take away from the readings.
Strengths: very entertaining and interesting syllabus and informative lectures
While Professor Gonzalez is the courses' strength, it is erroneous to call this course a seminar. Little discussion is encouraged.

I really liked the freedom of this course--the only official assignments were the three papers for which we could write about any work we wanted! It was nice to read the weekly stories and hear some great ideas from Professor Gonzlez-Prez (and classmates) during class. Some weeks when I was really busy, I wasn't able to read every story in-depth before class, but I always enjoyed the enthusiasm from Professor Gonzlez-Prez and felt motivated to catch up on the readings a bit after class. However, sometimes when I did get a bit behind and didn't quite follow everything in class, it might've been nice to have the slides available after class to jog my memory about some of the things we discussed in class. It could also be helpful to have a short summary slide available after class to capture the main ideas of the works we've discussed, especially for use when deciding what we want to write our papers about--sometimes I wasn't able to get all my notes/ideas down during class because I wanted to listen more attentively, so knowing that a short written summary would be available after class could be nice!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, because it was a really great, non-stressful environment to learn a foreign language in! Although since we aren't really encouraged to speak, I definitely didn't improve my spoken spanish, so I wouldn't recommend it to someone who's looking for that.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in reading more Spanish literature! This genre is very interesting and I think anyone would be able to enjoy it. Professor Gonzalez is very kind and the course information is easy to digest.
Definitely! Prof. Gonzalez-Perez is a wonderful professor and the subject of this class was so interesting. I didn't even really like science fiction before taking this class, now I love it.
It's an easy Spanish class for those looking to fulfill their L5 requirement with a literature focus. Not particularly interesting for those with a strong Latin American literature background.

I would recommend this course to another student because Professor Gonzlez-Prez is very enthusiastic and welcoming, and we discussed some really interesting works of science fiction that I probably wouldn't have come across otherwise! For me personally, it was tough sometimes to keep up with all the readings during weeks with a lot of assignments in other classes; however, our discussions were pretty relaxed, so I usually felt that I could catch up after class if need be. I'm not a native speaker, so I sometimes didn't quite follow everything in class, but I liked that we could choose our own stories/ideas for the papers!
